The world has seen strange change; yet here art thou</br>Mont Blanc, while generations pass away;</br>Thy vast heights glistening with untrodden snow,</br>On which the sun at eve imprints his ray;</br>There lingers yet the mild farewell of day.</br>The blue lake sleeps below in tranquil sheen;</br>There among Nature's miracles I'll pray</br>To Nature's Deity; how vast the scene!</br>The loveliest works of God — the grandest too are seen!

Here from our slumbers light we rise to feel</br>The consciousness of being; fresh and free</br>The soul pours forth its orisons with zeal</br>To the great Spirit of Eternity</br>That was, that is, and shall for ever be.</br>The fertile vallies, giant mountains, prove</br>The Omnipresence of the Deity;</br>Best emblems of his wisdom, power, and love,</br>Pervading all things here around, below, above.

The golden sun has colour'd all the woods!</br>Fresh views succeed; each brighter than the last!</br>There barren rocks are channell'd by the floods,</br>Here Flora's beauties cannot be surpast.</br>Lausanne, an universe of charms thou hast;</br>There Winter's fetter'd in his icy bed—</br>Steeps rise o'er steeps immeasurably vast—</br>While the rude crags projecting over-head</br>Strike in the stoutest hearts a momentary dread!

Th' ambitious rhododendron climbs the snow,</br>Pines darken round the mountain's sides, behold,</br>A thousand rills from icy caverns flow,</br>Rushing o'er rocks irregularly bold,</br>Where the tenacious sapling keeps its hold:</br>Below, the dark stream with collected force</br>Still rolling on as it has ever roll'd</br>Through the wide plains shapes its resistless course,</br>As rude as Ocean's self; as grand as is its source.

Look on these glorious wonders, think of Him,</br>Lord of a million worlds that have perchance</br>Greater phenomena, mine eyes grow dim,</br>With gazing on these heights, as we advance</br>Now all things seem envelop'd in a trance,</br>Save when at times the avalanche doth fall,</br>Startling the ear; still at a vast distance</br>The masses of thick-ribbed ice appal</br>The soul, as if they form'd the world's extremest wall!

The prospect lengthens, far and far beneath</br>See cities, mansions, beautifully placed,</br>While the smoke rises in a frequent wreath</br>From cottages by greenest arbours graced.</br>These, like man's proudest works, may be defaced</br>By war's unsparing hand; but yonder trees,</br>Self-planted, by thick-woven shrubs embraced;</br>They with their towering grandeur long will please—</br>How can the spoiler's axe fell forests such as these?

The buoyancy of spirits, the wild hope</br>Of something indefinable, the joy</br>Of giving thus to all my feelings scope,</br>Feelings, which man's injustice can't destroy;</br>These bring back former years, and I'm a boy</br>Joyful as sailor in his bounding bark;</br>Whose rapid course no sudden squalls annoy;</br>Wild as the stag that spurns his narrow park,</br>Light as the young chamois, blythe as the mountain lark!

Is not the soul immortal?  Whence its thought?</br>Its constant aspirations after bliss?</br>Its vast capacity for good, if nought</br>But a fortuitous element it is?</br>Away, nor preach a doctrine such as this.</br>For by yon blessed sun-rise there's a road,</br>Be but our faith unmoved, we cannot miss,</br>That leads us to that ever-blest abode;</br>Where Mind perceives all things, not as here, thro' a cloud.

At Vevai lies our Ludlow, there he dwelt,</br>The patriot exile; there he loved to roam;</br>There to the Father of all Mercies knelt;</br>There Freedom woo'd him in her own sweet home,</br>Presenting to his view an ample tome</br>Wherein was writ (in characters how true)</br>That an unyielding spirit doth become</br>Man, when the many govern'd by the few</br>Give to their masters praise that to their God is due.

Yes, the fresh air that circumfused around</br>Bids us think nobly, mountains, too, sublime</br>The soul; the free-wing'd things that here abound,</br>Tell us that passive virtue is a crime,</br>When tyrants would destroy the work of time!</br>Gaze on, thy feelings here will teach thee more</br>Than doubtful legends, or than lying rhyme;</br>Gaze on; and Heaven's magnificence adore!</br>Does not thine heart exult now to its very core?

But gloomy Calvin, how couldst thou prevail</br>With thy dark doctrines, and ascetic pride,</br>Where the ripe harvest smiles along the vale,</br>Where glows the vintage near Lake Leman's tide,</br>And all was mirth and cheerfulness beside?</br>Why didst thou not to northern regions hie,</br>Or in some dreary wilderness abide?</br>Why spread thy, faith where Heav'n and earth deny</br>The truths of thy heart-withering creed of destiny?

Yet Genius, eagle-eyed, has dared to raise</br>The torch of truth on high, and here his few,</br>His favour'd, sons look'd up, with unblench'd gaze,</br>On its eternal brightness; those who knew</br>The dignity of man and prized it too.</br>Alas!  to her, whose philosophic mind</br>Shew'd more than manly strength, a long adieu!</br>What, though her thoughts were somewhat too refin'd;</br>She yet was Freedom's daughter — Pride of womankind!

Sweet wanderer!  art thou not happier now,</br>Climbing the, mountain steep with fairy feet,</br>Thy cheeks carnation'd with health's vivid glow,</br>Not flushing with the ball-room's impure heat?</br>Is not thy simple rural feast, more sweet</br>Than gorgeous suppers, and the lovely things</br>That court thy steps, companions far more meet</br>For Nature's child, than those poor vain worldlings,</br>Who taint a woman's heart, then pierce it with their stings?

Thou might'st a model to Canova be</br>For young Diana, with thy steps of lightness;</br>And none of living sculptors, none, save he</br>Could image forth thy look of angel brightness.</br>His Psyche's scarce excels thy bosom's whiteness</br>Such as thou art, all-beauteous, and all-fair,</br>Oh, may'st thou never trust the world's politeness,</br>But always breathe with joy as pure an air,</br>Fresh as is yon wild flower, that shuns the sun's full glare?

Had man no other duties he might live</br>In yonder vale; his second Paradise;</br>Enjoying all that pure content can give;</br>And while he lives, be, without learning, wise,</br>Winning by silent prayer his heavenly prize.</br>But this must never be:  he can't forsake</br>His post, though stung by calumny and lies.</br>No!  rather let him be the more awake!</br>Give back his foemen blows that he is forced to take.

It is the lot of all to be reviled,</br>And who can hope to 'scape that general lot?</br>Not I; the traitor-friend, who lately smiled</br>And cringed before me, now remembers not</br>Past favours; what, are benefits forgot?</br>Aye more, not mere ingratitude, but hate;</br>Hate, with his ready sponge, will quickly blot</br>Out from the memory's tablet sign or date</br>Of friendship there; and then hypocrisy will prate!

No matter; tares will grow up with the wheat;</br>And none but knaves deem all mankind the same.</br>Though in society there be deceit,</br>Yet there prevails the love of honest fame;</br>Still on her altars Friendship's holy flame</br>Burns undiminished; misanthropes may rail</br>And sceptics smile, yet many could I name</br>Whose generous zeal was never known to fail,</br>Even in the hour of need, but then did most prevail.

The true friend's heart as yonder lake is calm;</br>Pure as yon snows, but firm as mountain rocks:</br>His voice is as the glowing morn, a balm</br>To the hurt mind that's felt the world's rough shocks.</br>His looks as cheerful as the sun's bright locks.</br>This high-soul'd being fearlessly will shield</br>A failing brother from the scorner's mocks.</br>Oh!  when the book of life shall be unseal'd</br>How gladly shall his name by Angels be reveal'd!

Evils there are, but many self-created</br>In this our busy world; why should we grieve</br>And murmur at our destiny, when fated</br>To be alone; why should we learn to weave</br>The web of thought too finely, to deceive</br>Ourselves, not others; still where'er thou art,</br>'Mid cities, or near cottages, relieve</br>The poor man's wants, thou wilt perform thy part</br>Well on the stage of life, and blunt e'en envy's dart!

Adieu, sweet country; of Helvetia's wrongs,</br>Even in my childhood, have I thought, and wept</br>When the war-cry was heard, where late the songs</br>Of Innocence spread mirth around; where slept</br>The child securely; where the goat-herd kept</br>His flocks untroubled, then the spoiler came,</br>Treading in innocent blood where'er he stept—</br>Hell's horrid offspring — Anarchy his name:</br>Affecting Freedom's voice fair Freedom's cause to shame.

Had France no Washingtons, Timoleons then</br>To point the way to Virtue's temple?  read</br>The latest records of Corinna's pen</br>And Gallia's woes will make thy bosom bleed.</br>The plant she nourish'd was a poisonous weed;</br>Her friends were foes, none prized the golden mean;</br>Each wild lawgiver had his separate creed;</br>All spoke in vain, the soldier rush'd between,</br>Th' imperial consul's pomp then closed th' eventful scene.

All things have their alloy; go southwards on,</br>See Italy, with varied landscapes gay,</br>A waste of sweets; the sun ne'er shone upon</br>A lovelier country, with a brighter ray;</br>Her very winter's softer than our May;</br>What are its natives now?  but imps from hell</br>Peopling a Paradise; though kinglings pray,</br>Those who degrade the human mind, as well</br>As Satan's self, 'gainst God's high purposes rebel!

Great Loyola!  how well thy sons succeed,</br>Dwarfing man's intellect to tread him down!</br>'Tis not enough that he must toil and bleed</br>To win for fellow-man, perchance, a crown;</br>But Superstition scares him with her frown.</br>Poor wretch, to beg, to flatter, stab, or steal;</br>Such are the vices Jesuits spare, alone</br>He loves; alas, to whom shall we appeal;</br>Oh!  when will monarchs learn to prize the general weal?

Here is Religion rob'd in rich attire,</br>To please the eve, not meliorate the heart;</br>Her pageantries, her glittering shrines, inspire</br>Devotion, in which morals have no part.</br>Does God delight in works of human mart?</br>He heedeth not the labour of man's hands;</br>He loves a soul devoid of guile and art;</br>Fear him, and love him, honour his commands,</br>But his all-perfect state no earthly pomp demands!

Quick are the Italian's feelings, prompt to wrong,</br>Why may they not be then alive to good?</br>In this sweet land of Music and of song,</br>The powers of the mind cannot be rude.</br>What then doth cause revenge, and acts of blood?</br>The vivid spirit that delights the muse,</br>Not the less willing, when she's fiercely woo'd;</br>Those impulses, how dangerous their abuse,</br>Which when directed well heroic acts produce.

'Twas here the light of science first broke forth</br>Amid the Gothic gloom of former ages;</br>Strange change, that light's diffused throughout the earth</br>Yet Barbarism's evil genius rages</br>E'en in a country long since famed for sages.</br>Invasions, civil wars, the jealous strife</br>Of princes, sully here th' historian's pages.</br>Awake, Italia's sons, awake to, life;</br>Throw off your foreign yoke, but scorn the inglorious knife.

Where Mind to marble gives a living grace,</br>Where Music's inspiration's fully felt:</br>Where Poetry all passions doth embrace</br>In language form'd to rouse the soul, or melt.</br>Where too the Muse of painting long has dwelt,</br>Can there be wanting courage-wakening men</br>Who have not to imperial tyrants knelt?</br>Be what ye were in ages past again,</br>Brave Milanese; the spoilers must re-seek their den.

And he who mid dark cypresses, and urns</br>Mourns o'er the buried mighty ones, in verse</br>Plaintive as nightingale's sweet song, he burns</br>T' avert from Lombardy's fair plains the curse</br>Of foreign slavery; what plague is worse?</br>In vain Bologna boasts her learned youth</br>In vain Firenze is of arts the nurse;</br>The prisoner hates the light, and lovely truth</br>When seen and not embraced heightens our woes in sooth.

But Leopold's kind genius yet presides</br>O'er rich Etruria's gardens, there is man</br>Comparatively happy; there resides</br>Smiling Content, though short may be the span</br>Of life, when princes do what good they can</br>They live for ever, not in marble busts,</br>While the poor subject's looks are pale and wan,</br>Not in some courtly verse that lauds their lusts,</br>But in that general wealth the stranger ne'er distrusts.

Th' exuberant produce Ceres here brings forth,</br>For here if husbanded she cannot fail,</br>Shews him at once the patriot monarch's worth;</br>The numerous houses studding hill and dale,</br>The fattening olive with its leaves so pale,</br>The cheerful peasantry, for years must pass</br>Ere laws that tend t' improve mankind can fail</br>In doing good, though scarce observed, alas!</br>Honor his memory more than monuments of brass.

I dream not of Utopias, nor a race</br>Of patriot kings; men may be bettered yet</br>If power be but administered with grace</br>Let monarchs shine in robes all gorgeous; let</br>The statesman, boast his star and coronet;</br>But as for those who first insult and scorn</br>Then catch within their Machiavelian net</br>The freeborn mind, though diadems adorn</br>Their brows, they hardly rank 'bove knaves ignobly born.

O Italy, rich in thy wood-cover'd mountains;</br>Thy rain-bow crown'd falls, and their ever-green fountains;</br>Thy skies in the thunder-storms even are bright,</br>With the rapid effulgence of rose-coloured light;</br>Thy shores do embrace, with their vast arms, the deep,</br>On whose blue tranquil bosom the sun loves to sleep;</br>While silvery mists round its islets are gleaming,</br>And gauze clouds along the horizon are streaming;</br>And Horace yet lives near his favourite hill</br>The delicate air breathes his poetry still;</br>Thy temples decay, still their ruins are seen,</br>Half grey through old time, or with ivy half green;</br>The fig-tree, pomegranate, pinastre, and vine,</br>The blossoming almond-tree's blushes, are thine;</br>But thy heroes are dust, and thy spirit is fled,</br>And the last of thy warriors, the White-Plumed, is dead.

Amid rich orange-trees, whose beauteous fruit</br>Glows like the western sun with deepen'd hue;</br>Where carelessly the southern plants up shoot,</br>Their green contrasting to the sky's deep blue</br>Think ye to find Arcadian fables true?</br>Vain hope; pale misery sallows every face,</br>Yet still to Nature's works full praise is due;</br>Oft in the peasant's wretched looks ye trace</br>Some lineaments unspoil'd as yet of manly grace.

Such were my thoughts when fast from Ischia's isle</br>The little vessel bore me, as the glare</br>Of noon-day soften'd itself down awhile,</br>A passing breeze o'er Baiae's bay so fair,</br>Gave a delicious fragrance to the air.</br>Sunny Neapolis, thy loveliness</br>Of clime, thy fruitage, thy luxurious fare,</br>Pamper thy sons with sensual excess;</br>Thy daughters dream of nought save lustful wantonness!

Here all is strenuous idleness!  the hum</br>Of men, like children bustling about nought</br>The bawling mountebank, and frequent drum</br>Are glorious substitutes for troublous thought;</br>While business is unheeded and unsought.</br>Here to the last they whirl around; the bier</br>Bears to the grave some noisy trifler caught</br>By death; the world's epitome is here;</br>The sight provokes a smile, yet mingled with a tear.

Give Italy one Master; she will thrive</br>Again, and triumph in her countless stores:</br>But bigots with their dead'ning influence drive</br>Wealth from her lands, and commerce from her shores;</br>While Heaven its choicest gifts in vain out-pours;</br>When Monks, in locust-swarms, oppress the soil,</br>When the vile spy of Government explores</br>The people's wealth; th' industrious will not toil</br>T' enrich their puny Masters with a greater spoil.</br>
